Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I finally read some classic novels (Tarzan of the Apes!) and I genuinely enjoyed most of the readings, long though they were. The complete lack of secondary sources made me really focus in on the novels, and I feel like my analytical skills were improved as a result.
Continued to improve my critical analysis and synthesis skills in literature.

Comprehensive overview on the various intersecting perspectives between the western civilization and the indigenous culture with the Jungle serving as the medium, 
great analysis and thoughts on how they are presented in popular culture, literature, poems, autobiographies, etc.
I came out with a better understanding and appreciation of the Jungle Book literature. I learned how to read more critically and write more coherently.

I developed an awareness and understanding of the Jungle Books genre, gained insight about the significance of that genre as a reflection of European imperialism, enjoyed an opportunity to hone my literary analysis and writing skills, and read some very entertaining and interesting books.

Strength: The one and only RGE.
Weaknesses: Days when professor RGE has spread himself thin with prestigious conferences and awards and we have a substitute teacher.
Strengths-Weaknesses>>0

Strengths: Very interesting overview of many books, all the books are connected through a theme yet pretty unique in their own ways so if you don't like one book you'll find others interesting. Good insight and grounded analysis.
Weaknesses: Reading load can be a bit high at times and some books are quite dense, a background in some fundamental philosophy or spanish history can be helpful.
This is a really good introduction to books that feature the jungle and Spanish/Latin American culture. It seems to not have a lot of structure, but overall was pretty interesting.
The strengths of the course are definitely the readings. I enjoyed many of the books and cannot think of very many improvements.

I thought the pacing of the course was very good, and the lectures were insightful and prompted student discussion well. I think the amount of writing was appropriate and the prompts thought provoking. I was surprised and impressed by the diversity of books included in the Jungle Books genre but also interested by the parallels among them, which were strong and invited reflection about the genre as a whole.

My only request would be to put it in a room with better windows in the future.

I found the course pretty fulfilling, and if you need a writing credit or a lit class, I would recommend it highly (if you're willing to do the readings!!!). I know that a lot of people skip readings in seminars, but I would highly advise against that in this case.

Yes, absolutely. This was one of the most enjoyable seminars I've ever been in. The surprisingly diverse selection of works within the realm of "jungle books" represented an intersection of genres that was placed into historical context. The professor is extremely knowledgeable of the history, culture and the authors surrounding the books. He knew one of the authors (Carpentier) personally. All in all, the course was thought-provoking and led to a surprising level of introspection and inspiration.
Absolutely recommend. RGE will make you passionate about whatever he is discussing. He commands the students respect and interest.
Definitely. Professor RGE overflows with insight and knowledge on the Jungle Books topics, he is also extremely well informed in the context. The GOAT.
If the topic interests you, this course could be really interesting.
I would absolutely recommend the class to another student. It was my favorite class this semester, in large part because of the readings and because of the professor's insights on them.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone looking for a refreshing literature experience who is ready to fully read and appreciate the books: the course is truly focused on the reading and driven by enthusiasm for the stories.
